help: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help # just for alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: c cd close connect cp disconnect du exec exit f find g get h help i info l list ls mkdir mv o open p ping put pwd q quit rcd rcp rdu rexec rf rfind rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rsh rshell rtree s scan sh shell t trace tree v verbose
h: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help # just for alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: c cd close connect cp disconnect du exec exit f find g get h help i info l list ls mkdir mv o open p ping put pwd q quit rcd rcp rdu rexec rf rfind rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rsh rshell rtree s scan sh shell t trace tree v verbose
exit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
quit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
q: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
trace: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace # just for alignment trace [LEVEL] t [LEVEL] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the tracing level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). When tracing is enabled, packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation are shown. The allowed values of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 text 2 binary payloads 3 binary all (payload + header) If no argument is given, increase the tracing level or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum. EXAMPLES # alignment TO DO
t: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace # just for alignment trace [LEVEL] t [LEVEL] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the tracing level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). When tracing is enabled, packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation are shown. The allowed values of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 text 2 binary payloads 3 binary all (payload + header) If no argument is given, increase the tracing level or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum. EXAMPLES # alignment TO DO
verbose: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose # just for alignment verbose [LEVEL] v [LEVEL] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the verbosity level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). The messages are written to stdout. The allowed values of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 errors 2 warnings 3 info 4 debug 5 internal libraries If no argument is given, increase the verbosity or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum.
v: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose # just for alignment verbose [LEVEL] v [LEVEL] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the verbosity level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). The messages are written to stdout. The allowed values of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 errors 2 warnings 3 info 4 debug 5 internal libraries If no argument is given, increase the verbosity or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum.
pwd: COMMAND # alignment pwd - show the name of current local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment pwd DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current local working directory. The local working directory can be changed with the command cd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rpwd" for the remote analogous.
ls: COMMAND # alignment ls - list local directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment ls # just for alignment ls [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -S show files size -s, --sort-size sort by size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rls" for the remote analogous.
tree: COMMAND # alignment tree - list local directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment tree # just for alignment tree [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -S show files size -s, --sort-size sort by size EXAMPLES # alignment /tmp> tree |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rtree" for the remote analogous.
find: COMMAND # alignment find - search for local files SYNOPSIS # alignment find # just for alignment find [OPTION]... [DIR] f [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Search for files and directories based on the given filters the local DIR, or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. Each result of find is memorized and can be used further with any command that accept local paths by specifying the identifier shown by find. For instance, you can search a file by name (i.e. find -n usefulname) and then perform a local action over it (e.g. rm $a1) or even a transfer action (e.g. put $a1). OPTIONS # alignment -i, --insensitive make filename filtering case insensitive -l show more details -n, --name pattern filter by filename -r, --regex pattern filter by filename using regular expression -t, --type ftype filter by file type EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. List current local directory (no filters) /tmp> find $a1 FILE2 $a2 dir1 $a3 dir1/file $a4 dir2 $a5 file1 2. List local directory (no filters) /tmp> find dir1 $b3 dir1/file 3. Finding by name /tmp> find -n file $c1 dir1/file $c2 file1 4. Finding by name, case insensitive /tmp> find -in file $d1 FILE2 $d2 dir1/file $d3 file1 5. Finding by regex /tmp> find -r file[0-9] $e1 file1 6. Finding by regex, case insensitive /tmp> find -ir file[0-9] $f1 FILE2 $f2 file1 7. Finding by name, files only /tmp> find -in dir1 -t f $g1 dir1/file SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rfind" for the remote analogous.
f: COMMAND # alignment find - search for local files SYNOPSIS # alignment find # just for alignment find [OPTION]... [DIR] f [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Search for files and directories based on the given filters the local DIR, or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. Each result of find is memorized and can be used further with any command that accept local paths by specifying the identifier shown by find. For instance, you can search a file by name (i.e. find -n usefulname) and then perform a local action over it (e.g. rm $a1) or even a transfer action (e.g. put $a1). OPTIONS # alignment -i, --insensitive make filename filtering case insensitive -l show more details -n, --name pattern filter by filename -r, --regex pattern filter by filename using regular expression -t, --type ftype filter by file type EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. List current local directory (no filters) /tmp> find $a1 FILE2 $a2 dir1 $a3 dir1/file $a4 dir2 $a5 file1 2. List local directory (no filters) /tmp> find dir1 $b3 dir1/file 3. Finding by name /tmp> find -n file $c1 dir1/file $c2 file1 4. Finding by name, case insensitive /tmp> find -in file $d1 FILE2 $d2 dir1/file $d3 file1 5. Finding by regex /tmp> find -r file[0-9] $e1 file1 6. Finding by regex, case insensitive /tmp> find -ir file[0-9] $f1 FILE2 $f2 file1 7. Finding by name, files only /tmp> find -in dir1 -t f $g1 dir1/file SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rfind" for the remote analogous.
du: COMMAND # alignment du - estimate disk usage of local files SYNOPSIS # alignment du # just for alignment du FILE DESCRIPTION # alignment Estimate the disk usage of FILE (which could be either a file or a directory). If FILE is not specified, the disk usage of the current local directory is estimated instead. OPTIONS # alignment -h, --human print size in human readable format (e.g. 17K) SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rdu" for the remote analogous.
cd: COMMAND # alignment cd - change local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment cd # just for alignment cd [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current local working directory to DIR or to the user's home directory if DIR is not specified. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcd" for the remote analogous.
mkdir: COMMAND # alignment mkdir - create a local directory SYNOPSIS # alignment mkdir # just for alignment mkdir DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the local directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmkdir" for the remote analogous.
cp: COMMAND # alignment cp - copy files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment cp # just for alignment cp SOURCE DEST cp SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "cp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "cp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcp" for the remote analogous.
mv: COMMAND # alignment mv - move files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment mv # just for alignment mv SOURCE DEST mv SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Move local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "mv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "mv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmv" for the remote analogous.
rm: COMMAND # alignment rm - remove files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment rm # just for alignment rm [FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove local FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rrm" for the remote analogous.
exec: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec # just for alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND : COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". Currently supported only for Unix. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
:: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec # just for alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND : COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". Currently supported only for Unix. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
shell: COMMAND # alignment shell - start a local shell SYNOPSIS # alignment shell # just for alignment shell sh DESCRIPTION # alignment Start a local shell using the user's preferred shell. Differently from exec, this really opens a pseudo terminal (ssh style). Currently supported only for Unix. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rshell" for the remote analogous.
sh: COMMAND # alignment shell - start a local shell SYNOPSIS # alignment shell # just for alignment shell sh DESCRIPTION # alignment Start a local shell using the user's preferred shell. Differently from exec, this really opens a pseudo terminal (ssh style). Currently supported only for Unix. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rshell" for the remote analogous.
rpwd: COMMAND # alignment rpwd - show the name of current remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rpwd DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current remote working directory. The remote working directory can be changed with the command rcd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help pwd" for the local analogous.
rls: COMMAND # alignment rls - list remote directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment rls # just for alignment rls [OPTION]... [DIR] rls [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -S show files size -s, --sort-size sort by size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help ls" for the local analogous.
rtree: COMMAND # alignment rtree - list remote directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment rtree # just for alignment rtree [OPTION]... [DIR] rtree [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -S show files size -s, --sort-size sort by size EXAMPLES # alignment bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help tree" for the local analogous.
rfind: COMMAND # alignment rfind - search for remote files SYNOPSIS # alignment rfind # just for alignment rfind [OPTION]... [DIR] rf [OPTION]... [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Search for files and directories based on the given filters the remote DIR, or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified. Each result of rfind is memorized and can be used further with any command that accept local paths by specifying the identifier shown by find. For instance, you can search a file by name (i.e. find -n usefulname) and then perform a local action over it (e.g. rrm $a1) or even a transfer action (e.g. get $a1). OPTIONS # alignment -i, --insensitive make filename filtering case insensitive -l show more details -n, --name pattern filter by filename -r, --regex pattern filter by filename using regular expression -t, --type ftype filter by file type EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. List current remote directory (no filters) bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find $a1 FILE2 $a2 dir1 $a3 dir1/file $a4 dir2 $a5 file1 2. List remote directory (no filters) bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find dir1 $b3 dir1/file 3. Finding by name bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -n file $c1 dir1/file $c2 file1 4. Finding by name, case insensitive bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -in file $d1 FILE2 $d2 dir1/file $d3 file1 5. Finding by regex bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -r file[0-9] $e1 file1 6. Finding by regex, case insensitive bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -ir file[0-9] $f1 FILE2 $f2 file1 7. Finding by name, files only bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -in dir1 -t f $g1 dir1/file SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help find" for the local analogous.
rf: COMMAND # alignment rfind - search for remote files SYNOPSIS # alignment rfind # just for alignment rfind [OPTION]... [DIR] rf [OPTION]... [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Search for files and directories based on the given filters the remote DIR, or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified. Each result of rfind is memorized and can be used further with any command that accept local paths by specifying the identifier shown by find. For instance, you can search a file by name (i.e. find -n usefulname) and then perform a local action over it (e.g. rrm $a1) or even a transfer action (e.g. get $a1). OPTIONS # alignment -i, --insensitive make filename filtering case insensitive -l show more details -n, --name pattern filter by filename -r, --regex pattern filter by filename using regular expression -t, --type ftype filter by file type EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. List current remote directory (no filters) bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find $a1 FILE2 $a2 dir1 $a3 dir1/file $a4 dir2 $a5 file1 2. List remote directory (no filters) bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find dir1 $b3 dir1/file 3. Finding by name bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -n file $c1 dir1/file $c2 file1 4. Finding by name, case insensitive bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -in file $d1 FILE2 $d2 dir1/file $d3 file1 5. Finding by regex bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -r file[0-9] $e1 file1 6. Finding by regex, case insensitive bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -ir file[0-9] $f1 FILE2 $f2 file1 7. Finding by name, files only bob-debian.shared:/ - /tmp> find -in dir1 -t f $g1 dir1/file SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help find" for the local analogous.
rdu: COMMAND # alignment rdu - estimate disk usage of remote files SYNOPSIS # alignment rdu # just for alignment rdu [FILE] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Estimate the disk usage of FILE (which could be either a file or a directory). If FILE is not specified, the disk usage of the current remote directory is estimated instead. OPTIONS # alignment -h, --human print size in human readable format (e.g. 17K) SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help du" for the remote analogous.
rcd: COMMAND # alignment rcd - change remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rcd # just for alignment rcd [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current remote working directory to DIR or to the root of the current sharing if no DIR is specified. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcd dir bob-debian.music:/dir - /tmp> rcd subdir bob-debian.music:/dir/subdir - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cd" for the local analogous.
rmkdir: COMMAND # alignment rmkdir - create a remote directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rmkdir # just for alignment rmkdir DIR rmkdir [SHARING_LOCATION] DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the remote directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmkdir newdir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcd newdir bob-debian.music:/newdir - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mkdir" for the local analogous.
rcp: COMMAND # alignment rcp - copy files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rcp # just for alignment rcp SOURCE DEST rcp SOURCE... DIR rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rcp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rcp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcp f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcp f1 f2 dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cp" for the local analogous.
rmv: COMMAND # alignment rmv - move files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rmv # just for alignment rmv SOURCE DEST rmv SOURCE... DIR rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Move remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rmv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rmv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmv f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f2 /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmv f1 f2 dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree dir +-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mv" for the local analogous.
rrm: COMMAND # alignment rrm - remove files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rrm # just for alignment rrm [FILE]... rrm [SHARING_LOCATION] [FILE]... SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove remote FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rrm f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 +-- f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rrm dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree +-- f1 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rm" for the local analogous.
rexec: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec # just for alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". Currently supported only for Unix. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
::: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec # just for alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". Currently supported only for Unix. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
rshell: COMMAND # alignment rshell - start a remote shell SYNOPSIS # alignment rshell # just for alignment rshell rsh DESCRIPTION # alignment Start a remote shell using the remote user's preferred shell. Differently from rexec, this really opens a pseudo terminal (ssh style). Currently supported only if the server is Unix. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help shell" for the local analogous.
rsh: COMMAND # alignment rshell - start a remote shell SYNOPSIS # alignment rshell # just for alignment rshell rsh DESCRIPTION # alignment Start a remote shell using the remote user's preferred shell. Differently from rexec, this really opens a pseudo terminal (ssh style). Currently supported only if the server is Unix. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help shell" for the local analogous.
scan: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan # just for alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. The scan time is two seconds unless it has been specified to es via -w seconds. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
s: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan # just for alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. The scan time is two seconds unless it has been specified to es via -w seconds. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
connect: COMMAND # alignment connect - connect to a remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment connect # just for alignment connect SERVER_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Connect to a remote server whose location is specified by SERVER_LOCATION. SERVER_LOCATION has the following syntax: <server_name> or <address>[:<port>] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SERVER_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SERVER_LOCATION is a valid <server_name> (e.g. alice-arch), a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is bound to. 2. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address> (e.g. 192.168.1.105), the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 3. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address>:<port> (e.g, 182.168.1.106:22020), the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1. and 2.), is performed on the port specified to eswith -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. There might be cases in which use connect is still required, for example for execute server commands (i.e. info, ping, list, rexec) which are not related to any sharings (you can use those commands if connected to a sharing, by the way). When possible, using "connect <server_name>" (1.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (2. and 3.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (3.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If already connected to a server, a successful connect execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. Remember that connect establish the connection with the server, but do not place you inside any server's sharing. Use open for that. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by server name (discover) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp 2. Connection by address (direct attempt, discover if fails) /tmp> connect 192.168.1.105 alice-arch - /tmp> 3. Connection by address and port (direct) /tmp> connect 89.1.2.84:22020 eve-kali - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment disconnect>, open
c: COMMAND # alignment connect - connect to a remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment connect # just for alignment connect SERVER_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Connect to a remote server whose location is specified by SERVER_LOCATION. SERVER_LOCATION has the following syntax: <server_name> or <address>[:<port>] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SERVER_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SERVER_LOCATION is a valid <server_name> (e.g. alice-arch), a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is bound to. 2. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address> (e.g. 192.168.1.105), the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 3. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address>:<port> (e.g, 182.168.1.106:22020), the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1. and 2.), is performed on the port specified to eswith -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. There might be cases in which use connect is still required, for example for execute server commands (i.e. info, ping, list, rexec) which are not related to any sharings (you can use those commands if connected to a sharing, by the way). When possible, using "connect <server_name>" (1.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (2. and 3.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (3.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If already connected to a server, a successful connect execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. Remember that connect establish the connection with the server, but do not place you inside any server's sharing. Use open for that. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by server name (discover) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp 2. Connection by address (direct attempt, discover if fails) /tmp> connect 192.168.1.105 alice-arch - /tmp> 3. Connection by address and port (direct) /tmp> connect 89.1.2.84:22020 eve-kali - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment disconnect>, open
disconnect: COMMAND # alignment disconnect - disconnect from a remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment disconnect DESCRIPTION # alignment Disconnect from the remote server to which the connection is established. While this command is the counterpart of connect, it can be used to close connections opened in other ways (i.e. with open). This differs from close which closes only the currently opened sharing without closing the connection. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> disconnect /tmp> connect SEE ALSO # alignment connect, close
open: COMMAND # alignment open - open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) SYNOPSIS # alignment open # just for alignment open SHARING_LOCATION o SHARING_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Open a sharing whose location is specified by SHARING_LOCATION SHARING_LOCATION has the following syntax: <sharing_name>[@<server_name>|<address>[:<port>]] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SHARING_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SHARING_LOCATION is a valid <sharing_name> (e.g. shared), a discover is performed for figure out to which server the sharing belongs to. 2. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<server_name>[:port] (e.g. shared@alice-arch) a discover is performed as well as in case 1. and the <server_name> and the <port> act only as a filter (i.e. the connection won't be established if they don't match). 3. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105) the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 4. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address>:<port> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105:12020) the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1., 2. and 3.), is performed on the port specified to es with -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. When possible, using the server name (1., 2. and 3.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (4.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (4.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If the sharing described by SHARING_LOCATION is found within the sharings of the server to which the connection is already established, it will be obviously opened without perform any kind of discover or new connection. If already connected to a server and/or a sharing, a successful open execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. If, for some reason, there is more than a sharing with the same name on the same network, open will try to connect to the one that is discovered first (in general it's unpredictable which will be). If you need a deterministic (and more safe) approach, consider using scan for discover the server manually (eventually followed by a consecutive info call for fetch more accurate details such as SSL certificate) then invoke open specifying the server details too (i.e. server name or address and port). In general, open doesn't require you to use connect before; the connection will be created for you automatically. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by sharing name (while connected) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 1b. Connection by sharing name (discover) /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 2. Connection by sharing name with server name filter (discover) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 3. Connection by sharing name with address (attempt direct, discover if fails) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 4. Connection by sharing name with address and port (direct) /tmp> open temp@192.168.1.105:12020 alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment close>, connect
o: COMMAND # alignment open - open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) SYNOPSIS # alignment open # just for alignment open SHARING_LOCATION o SHARING_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Open a sharing whose location is specified by SHARING_LOCATION SHARING_LOCATION has the following syntax: <sharing_name>[@<server_name>|<address>[:<port>]] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SHARING_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SHARING_LOCATION is a valid <sharing_name> (e.g. shared), a discover is performed for figure out to which server the sharing belongs to. 2. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<server_name>[:port] (e.g. shared@alice-arch) a discover is performed as well as in case 1. and the <server_name> and the <port> act only as a filter (i.e. the connection won't be established if they don't match). 3. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105) the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 4. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address>:<port> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105:12020) the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1., 2. and 3.), is performed on the port specified to es with -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. When possible, using the server name (1., 2. and 3.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (4.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (4.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If the sharing described by SHARING_LOCATION is found within the sharings of the server to which the connection is already established, it will be obviously opened without perform any kind of discover or new connection. If already connected to a server and/or a sharing, a successful open execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. If, for some reason, there is more than a sharing with the same name on the same network, open will try to connect to the one that is discovered first (in general it's unpredictable which will be). If you need a deterministic (and more safe) approach, consider using scan for discover the server manually (eventually followed by a consecutive info call for fetch more accurate details such as SSL certificate) then invoke open specifying the server details too (i.e. server name or address and port). In general, open doesn't require you to use connect before; the connection will be created for you automatically. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by sharing name (while connected) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 1b. Connection by sharing name (discover) /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 2. Connection by sharing name with server name filter (discover) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 3. Connection by sharing name with address (attempt direct, discover if fails) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 4. Connection by sharing name with address and port (direct) /tmp> open temp@192.168.1.105:12020 alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment close>, connect
close: COMMAND # alignment close - close the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment close c DESCRIPTION # alignment Close the currently opened sharing. If the sharing connection has been created directly with open instead of connect and then open, than the server connection is closed too (for symmetry). EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Close sharing connection only /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> close alice-arch - /tmp> close 2. Close both sharing and server connection /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> close /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment open, disconnect
get: COMMAND # alignment get - get files and directories from the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment get # just for alignment get [OPTION]... [REMOTE_FILE]... g [OPTION]... [REMOTE_FILE]... get [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [REMOTE_FILE]... g [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [REMOTE_FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Get files and directories from a remote sharing to the local machine. This command can be used for two similar purpose: 1. Download either files or directory from a "directory sharing" 2. Download a "file sharing" (i.e. a single file with a sharing name assigned to it). In case 1. a connection to the remote sharing have to be established in one of the following manners: 1a. Create a connection to the sharing with connect and/or open 1b. Provide a SHARING_LOCATION to the get command (e.g. get alice-arch temp) If execute while connected to a "directory sharing" (1.) the following rules are applied: - If REMOTE_FILEs arguments are given, then the specified remote files are downloaded into the local directory - If no REMOTE_FILE argument is given, then the entire sharing is downloaded into the local directory within a folder that has he same name as the sharing - If REMOTE_FILE is "*", then the entire sharing is downloaded into the local directory (without wrapping it into a folder) For download a "file sharing" (2.), get must be used in the form "get [SHARING_LOCATION]" (e.g. get alice-arch file) and there is no need to open the sharing before (since it's a file), as in case 1. REMOTE_FILE can be: - a path relative to the current remote working directory (rpwd), (e.g. afile, adir/afile) - a path absolute with respect to the sharing root, which is defined by a leading slash (e.g. /f1) The files will be placed into the current local directory (which can be changed with cd, inside or outside es). Directories are automatically downloaded recursively. If a remote file has the same name of a local file, you will be asked whether overwrite it or not. The default overwrite behaviour can be specified with the options -y (yes), -n (no), -N (overwrite if newer) and -S (overwrite if size is different). OPTIONS # alignment -c, --check performs a check of files consistency -h, --no-hidden doesn't copy hidden files -N, --overwrite-newer overwrite files only if newer -n, --overwrite-no never overwrite files -p, --preview do not transfer, just show a preview of what will happen -q, --quiet doesn't show progress -S, --overwrite-diff-size overwrite files only if size is different -s, --sync synchronize (same as -N but remove old files) -y, --overwrite-yes always overwrite files EXAMPLES # alignment 1. Get all the content of a directory sharing (wrapped into a folder) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get GET shared/f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- shared +-- f_remote_1 2. Get all the content of a directory sharing (into the current directory) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get * GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f_remote_1 3. Get specific files from a directory sharing /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 f_remote_2 f_remote_another alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get f_remote_1 u>f_remote_2 GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET f_remote_2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 |-- f_remote_1 +-- f_remote_2 4. Get without establish a connection before /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 /tmp> get shared GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- shared +-- f_remote_1 5. Get a file sharing (without establish a connection before) /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 /tmp> get f_share GET f_share [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f_share SEE ALSO # alignment open, put
g: COMMAND # alignment get - get files and directories from the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment get # just for alignment get [OPTION]... [REMOTE_FILE]... g [OPTION]... [REMOTE_FILE]... get [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [REMOTE_FILE]... g [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [REMOTE_FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Get files and directories from a remote sharing to the local machine. This command can be used for two similar purpose: 1. Download either files or directory from a "directory sharing" 2. Download a "file sharing" (i.e. a single file with a sharing name assigned to it). In case 1. a connection to the remote sharing have to be established in one of the following manners: 1a. Create a connection to the sharing with connect and/or open 1b. Provide a SHARING_LOCATION to the get command (e.g. get alice-arch temp) If execute while connected to a "directory sharing" (1.) the following rules are applied: - If REMOTE_FILEs arguments are given, then the specified remote files are downloaded into the local directory - If no REMOTE_FILE argument is given, then the entire sharing is downloaded into the local directory within a folder that has he same name as the sharing - If REMOTE_FILE is "*", then the entire sharing is downloaded into the local directory (without wrapping it into a folder) For download a "file sharing" (2.), get must be used in the form "get [SHARING_LOCATION]" (e.g. get alice-arch file) and there is no need to open the sharing before (since it's a file), as in case 1. REMOTE_FILE can be: - a path relative to the current remote working directory (rpwd), (e.g. afile, adir/afile) - a path absolute with respect to the sharing root, which is defined by a leading slash (e.g. /f1) The files will be placed into the current local directory (which can be changed with cd, inside or outside es). Directories are automatically downloaded recursively. If a remote file has the same name of a local file, you will be asked whether overwrite it or not. The default overwrite behaviour can be specified with the options -y (yes), -n (no), -N (overwrite if newer) and -S (overwrite if size is different). OPTIONS # alignment -c, --check performs a check of files consistency -h, --no-hidden doesn't copy hidden files -N, --overwrite-newer overwrite files only if newer -n, --overwrite-no never overwrite files -p, --preview do not transfer, just show a preview of what will happen -q, --quiet doesn't show progress -S, --overwrite-diff-size overwrite files only if size is different -s, --sync synchronize (same as -N but remove old files) -y, --overwrite-yes always overwrite files EXAMPLES # alignment 1. Get all the content of a directory sharing (wrapped into a folder) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get GET shared/f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- shared +-- f_remote_1 2. Get all the content of a directory sharing (into the current directory) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get * GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f_remote_1 3. Get specific files from a directory sharing /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> rls f_remote_1 f_remote_2 f_remote_another alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> get f_remote_1 u>f_remote_2 GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET f_remote_2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 |-- f_remote_1 +-- f_remote_2 4. Get without establish a connection before /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 /tmp> get shared GET f_remote_1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- shared +-- f_remote_1 5. Get a file sharing (without establish a connection before) /tmp> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 /tmp> get f_share GET f_share [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f_share SEE ALSO # alignment open, put
put: COMMAND # alignment put - put files and directories to the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment put # just for alignment put [OPTION]... [LOCAL_FILE]... p [OPTION]... [LOCAL_FILE]... put [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [LOCAL_FILE]... p [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [LOCAL_FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Put files and directories into a remote sharing. The remote sharing must be of type "directory sharing", otherwise put will fail. The connection to the remote sharing have to be established in one of the following manners: - Create a connection to the sharing with connect and/or open - Provide a SHARING_LOCATION to the put command (e.g. put alice-arch f1) If execute while connected to a "directory sharing" (1.) the following rules are applied: - If LOCAL_FILEs arguments are given, then the specified local files are uploaded into the remote directory - If no LOCAL_FILE argument is given, then the entire local folder is uploaded into the remote sharing within a folder that has he same name as the folder - If LOCAL_FILE is "*", then the entire local folder is uploaded into the remote sharing (without wrapping it into a folder) LOCAL_FILE must be a path to a local valid file or directory, either relative or absolute. The files will be placed into the current remote directory (which can be changed with rcd). The default remote directory is the root of the "directory sharing". Directories are automatically uploaded recursively. If a remote file has the same name of a local file, you will be asked whether overwrite it or not. The default overwrite behaviour can be specified with the options -y (yes), -n (no), -N (overwrite if newer) and -S (overwrite if size is different). OPTIONS # alignment -c, --check performs a check of files consistency -h, --no-hidden doesn't copy hidden files -N, --overwrite-newer overwrite files only if newer -n, --overwrite-no never overwrite files -p, --preview do not transfer, just show a preview of what will happen -q, --quiet doesn't show progress -S, --overwrite-diff-size overwrite files only if size is different -s, --sync synchronize (same as -N but remove old files) -y, --overwrite-yes always overwrite files EXAMPLES # alignment 1. Put all the content of a directory into a sharing (wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put PUT localdir/f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT localdir/f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 +-- localdir |-- f1 +-- f2 2. Put all the content of a directory into a sharing (not wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put * PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 |-- f1 +-- f2 3. Put specific files into a sharing (not wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f3 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put f1 f2 PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 |-- f1 +-- f2 4. Put without establish a connection before /tmp/localdir> put shared f1 PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp/localdir> rtree shared +-- f1 SEE ALSO # alignment open, get
p: COMMAND # alignment put - put files and directories to the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment put # just for alignment put [OPTION]... [LOCAL_FILE]... p [OPTION]... [LOCAL_FILE]... put [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [LOCAL_FILE]... p [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [LOCAL_FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Put files and directories into a remote sharing. The remote sharing must be of type "directory sharing", otherwise put will fail. The connection to the remote sharing have to be established in one of the following manners: - Create a connection to the sharing with connect and/or open - Provide a SHARING_LOCATION to the put command (e.g. put alice-arch f1) If execute while connected to a "directory sharing" (1.) the following rules are applied: - If LOCAL_FILEs arguments are given, then the specified local files are uploaded into the remote directory - If no LOCAL_FILE argument is given, then the entire local folder is uploaded into the remote sharing within a folder that has he same name as the folder - If LOCAL_FILE is "*", then the entire local folder is uploaded into the remote sharing (without wrapping it into a folder) LOCAL_FILE must be a path to a local valid file or directory, either relative or absolute. The files will be placed into the current remote directory (which can be changed with rcd). The default remote directory is the root of the "directory sharing". Directories are automatically uploaded recursively. If a remote file has the same name of a local file, you will be asked whether overwrite it or not. The default overwrite behaviour can be specified with the options -y (yes), -n (no), -N (overwrite if newer) and -S (overwrite if size is different). OPTIONS # alignment -c, --check performs a check of files consistency -h, --no-hidden doesn't copy hidden files -N, --overwrite-newer overwrite files only if newer -n, --overwrite-no never overwrite files -p, --preview do not transfer, just show a preview of what will happen -q, --quiet doesn't show progress -S, --overwrite-diff-size overwrite files only if size is different -s, --sync synchronize (same as -N but remove old files) -y, --overwrite-yes always overwrite files EXAMPLES # alignment 1. Put all the content of a directory into a sharing (wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put PUT localdir/f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT localdir/f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 +-- localdir |-- f1 +-- f2 2. Put all the content of a directory into a sharing (not wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 +-- f2 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put * PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 |-- f1 +-- f2 3. Put specific files into a sharing (not wrapped into a folder) /tmp/localdir> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> tree |-- f1 |-- f2 +-- f3 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rls f_remote_1 alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> put f1 f2 PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT f2 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 2 (1.4MB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp/localdir> rtree |-- f_remote_1 |-- f1 +-- f2 4. Put without establish a connection before /tmp/localdir> put shared f1 PUT f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB PUT outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s /tmp/localdir> rtree shared +-- f1 SEE ALSO # alignment open, get
list: COMMAND # alignment list - list the sharings of the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment list # just for alignment list [OPTION]... list [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List the sharings of the remote server to which the connection is established. OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
info: COMMAND # alignment info - show information about the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment info # just for alignment info [OPTION]... i [OPTION]... info [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... i [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Show information of the remote server to which the connection is established. The reported information are: - Server version - Server name - Server ip - Server port - Server discover port - Authentication enabled/disabled - SSL enabled/disabled - SSL certificate info (if enabled) - Sharings OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> info ================================ SERVER INFO Name: alice-arch Address: 192.168.1.105 Port: 12020 Discoverable: True Discover Port: 12019 Authentication: False SSL: True Remote execution: disabled Version: 0.6 ================================ SSL CERTIFICATE Common name: 192.168.1.105 Organization: Acme Corporation Organization Unit: Acme Corporation Email: acme@gmail.com Locality: Los Angeles State: Los Angeles Country: US Valid From: Apr 24 21:29:46 2020 GMT Valid To: Apr 24 21:29:46 2021 GMT Issuer: 192.168.1.105, Acme Corporation Signing: self signed ================================ SHARINGS DIRECTORIES - tmp ================================
i: COMMAND # alignment info - show information about the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment info # just for alignment info [OPTION]... i [OPTION]... info [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... i [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Show information of the remote server to which the connection is established. The reported information are: - Server version - Server name - Server ip - Server port - Server discover port - Authentication enabled/disabled - SSL enabled/disabled - SSL certificate info (if enabled) - Sharings OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> info ================================ SERVER INFO Name: alice-arch Address: 192.168.1.105 Port: 12020 Discoverable: True Discover Port: 12019 Authentication: False SSL: True Remote execution: disabled Version: 0.6 ================================ SSL CERTIFICATE Common name: 192.168.1.105 Organization: Acme Corporation Organization Unit: Acme Corporation Email: acme@gmail.com Locality: Los Angeles State: Los Angeles Country: US Valid From: Apr 24 21:29:46 2020 GMT Valid To: Apr 24 21:29:46 2021 GMT Issuer: 192.168.1.105, Acme Corporation Signing: self signed ================================ SHARINGS DIRECTORIES - tmp ================================
ping: COMMAND # alignment ping - test the connection with the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment ping # just for alignment ping [OPTION]... ping [OPTION]... [SERVER_LOCATION] SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Test the connectivity with the server by sending application-level messages. OPTIONS # alignment -c, --count count stop after count messages EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> ping [1] PONG from alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) | time=5.1ms [2] PONG from alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) | time=0.9ms ... /tmp> ping bob-debian -c 1 [1] PONG from bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) | time=9.3ms /tmp> ping 192.168.1.185 -c 1 [1] PONG from bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) | time=10.3ms
es: COMMAND # alignment es - client of the easyshare application SYNOPSIS # alignment es # just for alignment es [OPTION]... [COMMAND [COMMAND_OPTIONS]] DESCRIPTION # alignment Client of the easyshare network application. If no COMMAND is given, the interactive console is started. If COMMAND is a valid command, it is executed and the process quits unless the command is open. Type "help command" for the full documentation of a command. Commands: help show this help exit, quit, q exit from the interactive shell trace, t enable/disable packet tracing verbose, v change verbosity level scan, s scan the network for easyshare servers connect, c connect to a remote server disconnect disconnect from a remote server open, o open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) close close the remote sharing get, g get files and directories from the remote sharing put, p put files and directories in the remote sharing pwd show the name of current local working directory ls list local directory content l alias for ls -la tree list local directory contents in a tree-like format cd change local working directory mkdir create a local directory cp copy files and directories locally mv move files and directories locally rm remove files and directories locally find search for local files exec, : execute an arbitrary command locally shell, sh start a local shell rpwd show the name of current remote working directory rls list remote directory content rl alias for rls -la rtree list remote directory contents in a tree-like format rcd change remote working directory rmkdir create a remote directory rcp copy files and directories remotely rmv move files and directories remotely rrm remove files and directories remotely rfind search for local files rexec, :: execute an arbitrary command remotely rshell, rsh start a remote shell info, i show information about the remote server list list the sharings of the remote server ping test the connection with the remote server OPTIONS # alignment -d, --discover-port port port used for broadcast discovery messages -h, --help show this help --no-color don't print ANSI escape characters -t, --trace 0_or_1 enable/disable tracing -v, --verbose level set verbosity level -V, --version show the easyshare version -w, --discover-wait seconds time to wait for discovery responses EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Start the interactive shell (from which you can use any command) es 2. Scan the network for easyshare sharings es scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp 3. Get the content of a known sharing es get shared GET shared/f1 [===================] 100% 745KB/745KB GET outcome: OK Files 1 (745KB) Time 1s Avg. speed 1MB/s SEE ALSO # alignment SEE THE MAN PAGE FOR MORE INFO AND EXAMPLES
esd: COMMAND # alignment esd - server of the easyshare application SYNOPSIS # alignment esd # just for alignment esd [OPTION]... [SHARING [SHARING_NAME] [SHARING_OPTION]...] DESCRIPTION # alignment Server of the easyshare network application. Files and directories can be shared in one of the following manners: 1. By providing the path of the file/directory to share in the command line as SHARING 2. By creating a configuration file and specifying it with the option -c config The option 1. should be preferred for an easy one-shot sharing of a file or directory, since doesn't need the creation a configuration file, but has the limit that only a file or folder can be shared (unless the option -s is used before each sharing path (and eventually name or options). If given, SHARING must be a valid path to a local file or directory. SHARING_NAME is an optional name to assign to the sharing, as it will be seen by clients. If not given, the name of the file/directory is used instead. Currently the only supported SHARING_OPTION is the read-only flag, which can be enabled with -r, and denies any write operation on a directory sharing. The server can be configured either with a configuration file (2.) or by giving esd the options you need. The command line arguments have precedence over the corresponding setting of the configuration file (i.e. if you specify an option in both the configuration file and as an argument, the argument will be taken into account). The configuration file is composed of two parts. 1. Global section 2. Sharings sections Each line of a section has the form =. The available of the global section are: address discover_port name no_color password port rexec ssl ssl_cert ssl_privkey trace verbose The available of the sharings sections are: path readonly The first lines of the configuration file belongs to the global section by default. Each sharing section begins with "[SHARING_NAME]". If you omit the SHARING_NAME, the name of the shared file or directory will be used instead. See the section EXAMPLES for an example of a configuration file. You might consider using es-tools for some facilities, such as: - Create a default configuration file - Create a secure hash of a password, useful for avoid to give a plain password to esd. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --address address server address (default is primary interface) -c, --config config_path load settings from a server configuration file -d, --discover-port port port used to listen to discovery messages; 1 disables discovery (default is 12021) -e, --rexec enable rexec (remote execution) -h, --help show this help -n, --name name server name (default is server hostname) --no-color don't print ANSI escape characters -P, --password password server password, plain or hashed with es-tools -p, --port port server port (default is 12020) -s, --sharing sh_path [sh_name] [sh_options] sharing to serve --ssl-cert cert_path path to an SSL certificate --ssl-privkey privkey_path path to an SSL private key -t, --trace 0_or_1 enable/disable tracing -v, --verbose level set verbosity level -V, --version show the easyshare version EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Share a file esd /tmp/file 2. Share a directory, assigning it a name esd /tmp/shared_directory shared 3. Share multiples directories, one as read only esd -s /home/user -r -s /tmp temp 3. Share multiples directories, with a configuration file esd -c /home/user/.easyshare/esd.conf Configuration file example (esd.conf): # ===== SERVER SETTINGS ===== name=stefano-arch password=aSecurePassword port=12020 discover_port=12019 ssl=true ssl_cert="/tmp/cert.pem" ssl_privkey="/tmp/privkey.pem" ssl_privkey="/tmp/privkey.pem" rexec=false verbose=4 trace=1 # ===== SHARINGS ===== [download] path="/home/stefano/Downloads" [shared] path="/tmp/shared" readonly=true # Automatic sharing name [] path="/tmp/afile" SEE ALSO # alignment SEE THE MAN PAGE FOR MORE INFO AND EXAMPLES
es-tools: COMMAND # alignment es-tools - tools for administrators of easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment es-tools # just for alignment es-tools [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Collection of tools for administrators of easyshare servers. If neither -c nor -p is given, an interactive script is started and you will be asked what to do. OPTIONS # alignment -c, --generate-config generate default esd.conf file -h, --help show this help -p, --hash-password password generate an hash of the password -V, --version show the easyshare version EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Generate a default config file es-tools -c > /tmp/esd.conf 2. Create a secure hash of a password es-tools -p aSecurePassword 3. Start the interactive script es-tools What do you want to do? 1. Generate an hash of a password (hash) 2. Generate the default server configuration file 3. Generate a self signed SSL certificate SEE ALSO # alignment SEE THE MAN PAGE FOR MORE INFO AND EXAMPLES
usage: Type es --help for see es usage and options. Type help command for the full documentation of a command. Available commands are: help show this help exit, quit, q exit from the interactive shell trace, t enable/disable packet tracing verbose, v change verbosity level scan, s scan the network for easyshare servers connect, c connect to a remote server disconnect disconnect from a remote server open, o open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) close close the remote sharing get, g get files and directories from the remote sharing put, p put files and directories in the remote sharing pwd show the name of current local working directory ls list local directory content l alias for ls -la tree list local directory contents in a tree-like format cd change local working directory mkdir create a local directory cp copy files and directories locally mv move files and directories locally rm remove files and directories locally find search for local files exec, : execute an arbitrary command locally shell, sh start a local shell rpwd show the name of current remote working directory rls list remote directory content rl alias for rls -la rtree list remote directory contents in a tree-like format rcd change remote working directory rmkdir create a remote directory rcp copy files and directories remotely rmv move files and directories remotely rrm remove files and directories remotely rfind search for local files rexec, :: execute an arbitrary command remotely rshell, rsh start a remote shell info, i show information about the remote server list list the sharings of the remote server ping test the connection with the remote server
